title: One letter...
content:
Can anyone please let me know if you recognize the font. Just have the "a"

Thanks

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Capture d’écran 2013-05-04 à 13.21.26.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20130620213224/http:/typophile.com/files/Capture%20d%E2%80%99%C3%A9cran%202013-05-04%20%C3%A0%2013.21.26.png) | 8.28 KB |
author: Adrien Heury

comments.content:
It must be **[Clemente PDaa (Hairline)](http://web.archive.org/web/20130620213224/http:/www.findmyfont.com/index.php/fonts/font-preview?fset=Dafont-1&ffam=ClementePDaa%20-%20Hairline&fid=63adea3d67ab4c3579b8b428c2e51354&fsize=60&text=a&fit=1)** free font by Alan Prescott (Prescott Design, 2003)

------------------  
I found it using "Find my Font": [http://www.findmyfont.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20130620213224/http:/www.findmyfont.com/ "http://www.findmyfont.com")

Does the "s" in Clemente remind you of anything?  
It's a difficult letter to make...

hhp
You are right, 's' looks exactly like Helvetica-Thin ...

The very delicate modulation between the bowl and stem of the "a" was the initial clue. Very few people who implement such sophisticated details give their stuff away... Sadly though others often steal their stuff and give it away. Let's not help that along.

hhp
Go check the spacing of Clementine’s lowercase ‘j’ …
